Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I was exposed to French literature, more complex grammar structures, and difficult vocabulary.
I learned more about the basic grammar skills of French, and my ability to read French improved greatly due to the number of books we read.
I gained a deeper knowledge of many different types of French grammatical systems and how to use them in daily conversations. I also greatly broadened my vocabulary.
I learned a lot more french and became a lot more confident conversing and writing in the language.
We worked on fine-tuning grammar and practicing our written production.

I like the methods of integrating and learning. More one on one learning of how to speak and answer questions that are not related to the coursework would be great-- I doubt I have to talk about the characters of Jules et Jim to someone from Paris. Also the work sometimes felt like busywork and took much longer than necessary.

I think the course material could sometimes be a bit boring and I did not always feel engaged by what we were learning. At times, it also felt a bit basic.

I liked the texts that we looked at and found it interesting how all of these materials were woven together throughout the course.
The course did not have a lot of weaknesses in my opinion. It was very well organized and facilitated learning.
I feel like those who studied abroad before this class or placed into it as freshman were way ahead of those who took 120, and it just wasnt great to see that large of a difference everyday in class

Strengths: extremely well organized, great books and movies, and I greatly benefited from the nightly homework assignments that included written, spoken, and listening practice.

Weaknesses: none that I can think of! Definitely requires quite a bit of work, but absolutely worth it.
I thought this course was great, but some of the movies we watched weren't very engaging for me such as Jules et Jim.
Yeah, it's a great way to further your learning of the french language
I would recommend this course. I think it's a good way to improve your french, particularly if you're struggling with grammar or vocabulary.
Yes I would recommend the course because it helped me learn more french while cementing the foundational knowledge.
Unless youre already pretty good at French, switch into another language
Yes! This course is the absolute best way to go if you'd like to continue your study  of French and advance as a French listener, speaker, reader, and writer. 100% worth it.
Yes! This was a great course and I felt like I learned a lot.
